  • About

A cycling app

University project

Introduction

Switchback is an app that helps mountain bikers share their riding experiences. Users can track their rides, publish trail information, and organise events like races or dig days.

My role

I worked through most of the product design process and developed a prototype for iOS using PhoneGap.

Process

A user-centred design process was used to understand user needs and tailor solutions to meet their specific requirements.

Analysis

Determine the purpose of the product and the target audience

Design

Design solutions to user needs based on research insights

Evaluate

Carry out user-based assessment to evaluate designs against requirements

Iterate

Use knowledge gained from evaluation to improve design solutions

Analysis

Determine the purpose of the product and the target audience

Design

Design solutions to user needs based on research insights

Evaluate

Carry out user based assessment to evaluate designs against requirements

Iterate

Use knowledge gained from evaluation to improve design solutions

Analysis

Several research methods were used to understand users and the problem space.

Research

I conducted user interviews, blog studies, and competitor analysis to gather insights. Analysis and a focus on empathy helped dissect the problem. In the synthesis phase, I pieced the problem back together to arrive at a problem definition.

Blog studies

Blog studies revealed cycling apps such as Strava could harm mountain biking culture. I wanted to identify other patterns and deep dive into the issues uncovered from the study.

“Don’t go out for a ride and hit the same trail three times because you’re trying to get a KOM. That’s not riding. It’s just dumb.”

Flow mountain bike

“Don’t do Strava runs on weekends. Nobody cares if you are having the run of a lifetime. Pros don’t ride like dicks, and neither should you.”

NSMB

“Take for instance the geniuses who are riding illegal mountain bike trails, then posting their Strava segments for park rangers to see.”

Bike Mojo

Interviews

In the interviews, I allowed participants to talk openly about their experience with cycling apps then focused on specific problems related to the blog study findings.

Analysis

Using affinity mapping, I sorted research findings into themes to identify patterns.

Patterns found:
  • Strava users can have be antisocial when competing
  • Unsanctioned bike trails published online
  • Closure of privately built bike trails
  • Increase traffic on bike trails
  • Bikers littering on trails

Synthesis

Patterns and observations helped with empathy mapping and informed two personas. Each persona represents the pain points and goals of the potential users who were studied.

Problem definition

I created HMW questions to reframe the patterns into potential opportunities and identify the main problem area to focus my design efforts on.

  • How might we keep trails clean from trash?
  • How might we educate users in trail etiquette?
  • How might we help users improve their cycling skills?
  • How might we encourage positive social behaviour?
  • How might we encourage mountain bikers to ride safely?
  • How might we stop users publishing secret trail locations?

How might we prevent the closure of unsanctioned bike trails?

Specify scope

Mapping user stories helped identify the scope of the project. The chosen stories included features that I could create in the given time frame and would still give meaning to the app.

Design

After discovery, I went on to ideate possible solutions.

Ideation

Sketching allowed me to work through several ideas before committing to a solution. The chosen ideas were then developed into wireframes to flesh out the experience.

  • Sketches
  • Wireframes

Evaluate

Once the user journeys were drawn out, I created a low-fidelity prototype to validate the designs in user testing.

User testing

I went out and recruited members of my local mountain biking club to test the prototype, which provided insights into their thoughts and behaviours.

Summary of findings:
  • Difficulty finding where to create a group announcement
  • Participants wanted to share announcements in chat
  • Icons and navigation elements need labels
  • Difficulty finding group pages

Iterate

Recommendations for improvement gathered from the first round of testing informed a second design iteration.

Second round of design

I added labels to affordances and navigation items to improve learnability. Varied styles for tab elements and call to action buttons were also rethought to reduce confusion when trying to find group pages.

Design persona

During this stage, I began adding further design detail using a design persona.

A Design persona is an archetypal character designed to be like-minded to the user personas.

If a design persona is incorporated into a design successfully, the user will feel like they are interacting with a friend when using the app.

Read more

Interface design

Building out high-fidelity mockups in line with the second round of designs set the art direction and added personality to the app.

Implement

Finally, I built the app using a hybrid web app framework which allowed me to deploy web technology onto native mobile platforms like iOS or Android.

Outcome

Members of the mountain biking community liked the personality that came across in the designs and copy. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to validate if the designed solutions helped prevent trail closures.

Learnings

If I had more time, I would have carried out the second round of user testing and passed through the user-centred design process once more to validate the solutions.
